Identify or predict catalytic residues, active sites or other ligand-binding sites in protein sequences or structures.
Model or simulate protein-protein binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: Virtual screening is widely used for lead identification, lead optimization, and scaffold hopping during drug design and discovery. There are two broad categories of virtual screening techniques: ligand-based drug design (e.g. ligand similarity) and structure-based drug design (ligand docking) methods. Ligand similarity methods exploit structural similarities to known active ligands, whereas ligand docking methods use the 3D structure of a target protein to predict the binding modes and affinities of ligands to it.
children.definition: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).

comment: Virtual screening is used in drug discovery to search libraries of small molecules in order to identify those molecules which are most likely to bind to a drug target (typically a protein receptor or enzyme).
Methods aim to predict the position and orientation of a ligand bound to a protein receptor or enzyme.
children.definition: Model protein-ligand (for example protein-peptide) binding using comparative modelling or other techniques.

comment: This includes protein-protein interactions, protein-nucleic acid, protein-ligand binding etc. Methods might predict whether the molecules are likely to bind in vivo, their conformation when bound, the strength of the interaction, possible mutations to achieve bonding and so on.
children.definition: Model the structure of a protein in complex with a small molecule or another macromolecule.

comment: For functional properties that can be mapped to a sequence, use 'Sequence feature detection (protein)' instead.
children.definition: Predict the biological or biochemical role of a protein, or other aspects of a protein function.
The prediction of the degree of pathogenicity of a microorganism from analysis of molecular sequences.

comment: Protein SNP mapping maps and modesl the effects of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) on protein structure(s).  Methods might predict silent or pathological mutations.
children.definition: Predict the effect of point mutation on a protein structure, in terms of strucural effects and protein folding, stability and function.
Identification of protein, for example from one or more peptide identifications by tandem mass spectrometry.

comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.definition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Predict splicing alternatives or transcript isoforms from analysis of sequence data.

comment: Methods might require a pre-mRNA or genomic DNA sequence.
children.definition: Identify, predict or analyse splice sites in nucleotide sequences.
Predict, analyse, characterize or model splice sites, splicing events and so on, typically by comparing multiple nucleic acid sequences.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
Predict DNA tertiary structure.
Predict RNA tertiary structure.

Analyse some aspect of RNA/DNA folding, typically by processing sequence and/or structural data.  For example, compute folding energies such as minimum folding energies for DNA or RNA sequences or energy landscape of RNA mutants.

comment: Methods might identify thermodynamically stable or evolutionarily conserved structures.
children.definition: Predict structure of DNA or RNA.
Assign secondary structure from protein coordinate or experimental data.
Detect cysteine bridges (from coordinate data) in a protein structure.

comment: A free cysteine is neither involved in a cysteine bridge, nor functions as a ligand to a metal.
children.definition: Detect free cysteines in a protein structure.
Detect cysteines that are bound to metal in a protein structure.
Assign cysteine bonding state and disulfide bond partners in protein structures.
children.text: Protein cysteine and disulfide bond assignment

children.definition: Assign a protein tertiary structure (3D coordinates), or other aspects of protein structure, from raw experimental data.
The simulation of molecular (typically protein) conformation using a computational model of physical forces and computer simulation.

Retrieve an entry (or part of an entry) from a data resource that matches a supplied query. This might include some primary data and annotation. The query is a data identifier or other indexed term. For example, retrieve a sequence record with the specified accession number, or matching supplied keywords.
Retrieve resources from information systems matching a specific information need.
Recognise named entities, ontology concepts, tags, events, and dictionary terms within documents.
Extract structured information from unstructured ("free") or semi-structured textual documents.
Identify semantic relations among entities and concepts within a text, using text mining techniques.
Process and analyse text (typically scientific literature) to extract information from it.
Predict a network of gene regulation.
Detect polyA signals in nucleotide sequences.

comment: Quadruplex (4-stranded) structures are formed by guanine-rich regions and are implicated in various important biological processes and as therapeutic targets.
children.definition: Detect quadruplex-forming motifs in nucleotide sequences.
Find (and possibly render) short repetitive subsequences (repeat sequences) in (typically nucleotide) sequences.
Find and identify restriction enzyme cleavage sites (restriction sites) in (typically) DNA sequences, for example to generate a restriction map.

comment: An isochore is long region (> 3 KB) of DNA with very uniform GC content, in contrast to the rest of the genome. Isochores tend tends to have more genes, higher local melting or denaturation temperatures, and different flexibility. Methods might calculate fractional GC content or variation of GC content, predict methylation status of CpG islands etc. This includes methods that visualise CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence, for example plot isochores in a genome sequence.
children.definition: Find CpG rich regions in a nucleotide sequence or isochores in genome sequences.

comment: Chip-sequencing combines chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) with massively parallel DNA sequencing to generate a set of reads, which are aligned to a genome sequence.  The enriched areas contain the binding sites of DNA-associated proteins.  For example, a transcription factor binding site. ChIP-on-chip in contrast combines chromatin immunoprecipitation ('ChIP') with microarray ('chip').  "Peak-pair calling" is similar to "Peak calling" in the context of ChIP-exo.
children.definition: Identify putative protein-binding regions in a genome sequence from analysis of Chip-sequencing data or ChIP-on-chip data.
Identify binding sites in nucleic acid sequences that are statistically significantly differentially bound between sample groups.

comment: Methods might use RNA motifs, predicted intermolecular contacts, or RNA sequence-structure compatibility (inverse RNA folding).
children.definition: Predict RNA secondary structure (for example knots, pseudoknots, alternative structures etc).
Detect or predict transposons, retrotransposons / retrotransposition signatures etc.
Identify or predict nucleosome exclusion sequences (nucleosome free regions) in DNA.
Detect vector sequences in nucleotide sequence, typically by comparison to a set of known vector sequences.

comment: This is placeholder but does not comprehensively include all child concepts - please inspect other concepts under "Nucleic acid sequence analysis" for example "Gene prediction", for other feature detection operations.
Methods typically involve scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify features in nucleotide sequences such as functional sites or regions, typically by scanning for known motifs, patterns and regular expressions.
Predict the structure of a multi-subunit protein and particularly how the subunits fit together.
Identify or predict intrinsically disordered regions in proteins.
Find (scan for) known motifs, patterns and regular expressions in molecular sequence(s).

comment: Motifs and patterns might be conserved or over-represented (occur with improbable frequency).
children.definition: Discover new motifs or conserved patterns in sequences or sequence alignments (de-novo discovery).

comment: Look at "Protein feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_3092) and "Nucleic acid feature detection" (http://edamontology.org/operation_0415) in case more specific terms are needed.
children.definition: Predict, recognise and identify positional features in molecular sequences such as key functional sites or regions.
Predict, recognise, detect or identify some properties of a biomolecule.

comment: A micrograph can include particles in multiple different orientations and/or conformations. Particles are compared and organised into sets based on their similarity. Typically iterations of classification and alignment and are performed to optimise the final 3D EM map.
children.definition: Compare (align and classify) multiple particle images from a micrograph in order to produce a representative image of the particle.

comment: Includes methods that try to suggest the most likely biological unit for a given protein X-ray crystal structure based on crystal symmetry and scoring of putative protein-protein interfaces.
children.definition: Identify the architecture of a protein structure.
Assign molecular structure(s) to a group or category.

comment: Variants are typically classified by their position (intronic, exonic, etc.) in a gene transcript and (for variants in coding exons) by their effect on the protein sequence (synonymous, non-synonymous, frameshifting, etc.)
children.definition: Classify variants based on their potential effect on genes, especially functional effects on the expressed proteins.
Classifiication (typically of molecular sequences) by assignment to some taxonomic hierarchy.
Assign molecular sequence(s) to a group or category.
Assign molecular sequences, structures or other biological data to a specific group or category according to qualities it shares with that group or category.

comment: Special cases are: a) An operation that consumes no input (has no input arguments). Such operation is either a constant function, or an operation depending only on the underlying state. b) An operation that may modify the underlying state but has no output. c) The singular-case operation with no input or output, that still may modify the underlying state.
children.definition: A function that processes a set of inputs and results in a set of outputs, or associates arguments (inputs) with values (outputs).

comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.
FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.

comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).
Alignment format for start and end of matches between sequence pairs.
NBRF/PIR entry sequence format.
EMBOSS debugging trace feature format of full internal data content.
Format of a regular expression pattern from the Prosite database.
SMILES ARbitrary Target Specification (SMARTS) format for chemical structure specification, which is a subset of the SMILES line notation.
Chemical structure specified in Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System (SMILES) line notation.

comment: This format was influenced by the OWL Abstract Syntax and the DL style syntax.
children.definition: A syntax for writing OWL class expressions.
Chemical structure specified in IUPAC International Chemical Identifier (InChI) line notation.
Alignment format for score values for pairs of sequences.
Format of Affymetrix data file of information about (raw) expression levels of the individual probes.
Abstract format used by MedLine database.
Alphabet for any protein sequence with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for any protein sequence without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for any protein sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.

comment: Non-sequence characters may be used for gaps and translation stop.
children.definition: Alphabet for a protein sequence with possible ambiguity, unknown positions and non-sequence characters.

Tab-delimited text file format used by Eland - the read-mapping program distributed by Illumina with its sequencing analysis pipeline - which maps short Solexa sequence reads to the human reference genome.
Affymetrix data file format for information about experimental conditions and protocols.
exact_synonyms: Affymetrix experimental conditions data file format

children.definition: PHD sequence trace format to store serialised chromatogram data (reads).

comment: The hits are relatives to a SCOP or CATH family and are found from a search of a sequence database.
children.definition: Format of EMBASSY domain hits file (DHF) of hits (sequences) with domain classification information.

comment: An InChIKey identifier is not human- nor machine-readable but is more suitable for web searches than an InChI chemical structure specification.
children.definition: The InChIKey (hashed InChI) is a fixed length (25 character) condensed digital representation of an InChI chemical structure specification. It uniquely identifies a chemical compound.

comment: GCG SSF (single sequence file) file format.
children.definition: GCG sequence file format.
Intelligenetics sequence format (strict version).
Format used by the HMMER package for of an alignment of a hidden Markov model against a sequence database.
Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence (characters ACGTU only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters .
Alphabet for a DNA sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for an RNA sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a DNA sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a DNA sequence (characters ACGT only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a DNA sequence (characters ACGT only) without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a DNA sequence with possible ambiguity, unknown positions and non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence (characters ACGTU only) without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters .
Alphabet for an RNA sequence (characters ACGU only) without unknown positions, ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for an RNA sequence (characters ACGU only) with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for an RNA sequence with possible ambiguity and unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for an RNA sequence with possible ambiguity, unknown positions and non-sequence characters.

comment: Non-sequence characters may be used for example for gaps.
children.definition: Alphabet for a nucleotide sequence with possible ambiguity, unknown positions and non-sequence characters.
Format of multiple sequences aligned by DIALIGN package.
Format of PHYLIP discrete states data.
Personal Genome SNP (pgSnp) format for sequence variation tracks (indels and polymorphisms), supported by the UCSC Genome Browser.

comment: BIOM is a recognised standard for the Earth Microbiome Project, and is a project supported by Genomics Standards Consortium. Supported in QIIME, Mothur, MEGAN, etc.
children.definition: The BIological Observation Matrix (BIOM) is a format for representing biological sample by observation contingency tables in broad areas of comparative omics. The primary use of this format is to represent OTU tables and metagenome tables.
AFG is a single text-based file assembly format  that holds read and consensus information together

comment: ISA-TAB is based on MAGE-TAB. Other than tabular, the ISA model can also be represented in RDF, and in JSON (compliable with a set of defined JSON Schemata).
children.definition:
The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from 
experiments employing a combination of technologies.
Report format for restriction enzyme recognition sites used by REBASE database.

comment: Galaxy allows BED files to contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns, some other implementations do not.
children.definition: Tabular format of chromosome names and sizes used by Galaxy.
Human ENCODE broad peak format.

comment: Format that covers both the broad peak format and narrow peak format from ENCODE.
children.definition: Human ENCODE narrow peak format.

comment: Format that covers both the broad peak format and narrow peak format from ENCODE.
children.definition: Human ENCODE peak format.

comment: Tab delimited data in strict BED format - no non-standard columns allowed; column count forced to 6
children.definition: BED file format where each feature is described by chromosome, start, end, name, score, and strand.

comment: Tab delimited data in strict BED format - no non-standard columns allowed; column count forced to 12
children.definition: A BED file where each feature is described by all twelve columns.

comment: Galaxy allows BED files to contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns, some other implementations do not.
children.definition: Browser Extensible Data (BED) format of sequence annotation track that strictly does not contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns.

comment: BED detail format includes 2 additional columns (http://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat#format1.7) and BED 15 includes 3 additional columns for experiment scores (http://genomewiki.ucsc.edu/index.php/Microarray_track).
children.definition: Browser Extensible Data (BED) format of sequence annotation track, typically to be displayed in a genome browser.

comment: This format is used in Protege 4.
children.definition: A superset of the "Description-Logic Knowledge Representation System Specification from the KRSS Group of the ARPA Knowledge Sharing Effort".
Report format for restriction enzyme recognition sites used by EMBOSS restover program.
Entry format of PDB database in PDB format.
Sequence assembly project file EXP format.
Article format of the PubMed Central database.
Report format for inverted repeats in a nucleotide sequence (format generated by the Sanger Centre inverted program).

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.
FASTQ Illumina 1.3 short read format.

comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.
FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.

comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).
FASTQ short read format with phred quality.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.
FASTQ Solexa/Illumina 1.0 short read format.
FASTQ short read format ignoring quality scores.

comment: This concept may be used for non-standard FASTQ short read-like formats.
children.definition: A text format resembling FASTQ short read format.

comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
children.definition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.
Amino acid index format used by the AAindex database.

comment: Galaxy allows BED files to contain non-standard fields beyond the first 3 columns, some other implementations do not.
children.definition: Tabular format of chromosome names and sizes used by Galaxy.
Format of bibliographic reference as used by the PubMed database.
Mase program sequence format.
axt format of alignments, typically produced from BLASTZ.

comment: Typically generated by Multiz and TBA aligners; can be displayed in a genome browser like a sequence annotation track. This should not be confused with MIRA Assembly Format or Mutation Annotation Format.
children.definition: Multiple Alignment Format (MAF) supporting alignments of whole genomes with rearrangements, directions, multiple pieces to the alignment, and so forth.

A report format for the kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reaction(s) in a format generated by EMBOSS findkm. This includes Michaelis Menten plot, Hanes Woolf plot, Michaelis Menten constant (Km) and maximum velocity (Vmax).
Format of Affymetrix data file of information about (normalised) expression levels of the individual probes.
The format of an entry from the HET group dictionary (HET groups from PDB files).
SQL (Structured Query Language) is the de-facto standard query language (format of queries) for querying and manipulating data in relational databases.
Codata entry format.

comment: The format is clustal-like and includes annotation of domain family classification information.
children.definition: EMBASSY 'domain alignment file' (DAF) format, containing a sequence alignment of protein domains belonging to the same SCOP or CATH family.
Report format on PCR primers and hybridisation oligos as generated by Whitehead primer3 program.
A shorthand non-XML serialisation of Resource Description Framework model, designed with human-readability in mind.
Format of results of a sequence database search using some variant of Smith Waterman.
EMBOSS alignment format for debugging trace of full internal data content.
PHYLIP file format for continuous quantitative character data.

comment: Currently identical to genpept format
children.definition: Refseq protein entry sequence format.
A human-readable encoding for the Web Ontology Language (OWL).
The SAMPLE file format contains information about each individual i.e. individual IDs, covariates, phenotypes and missing data proportions, from a GWAS study.
Alphabet for the consensus of two or more molecular sequences.
Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but possibly with non-sequence characters.

comment: Reflects a UCSC Browser DB table.
children.definition: Cytoband format for chromosome cytobands.

comment: JCAMP-DX is an ASCII based format and therefore not very compact even though it includes standards for file compression.
children.definition: A standardized file format for data exchange in mass spectrometry, initially developed for infrared spectrometry.
LAV format of alignments generated by BLASTZ and LASTZ.

comment: Pcons ranks protein models by assessing their quality based on the occurrence of recurring common three-dimensional structural patterns. Pcons returns a score reflecting the overall global quality and a score for each individual residue in the protein reflecting the local residue quality.
children.definition: Format of output of the Pcons Model Quality Assessment Program (MQAP).

comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
children.definition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).

comment: genePred format has 3 main variations (http://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat#format9 http://www.broadinstitute.org/software/igv/genePred). They reflect UCSC Browser DB tables.
children.definition: genePred table format for gene prediction tracks.
Format of the model of random sequences used by MEME.
Reporter Code Count-A data file (.csv) output by the Nanostring nCounter Digital Analyzer, which contains gene sample information, probe information and probe counts.
An MDL Molfile is a file format for holding information about the atoms, bonds, connectivity and coordinates of a molecule.

comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
children.definition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
Format of local RNA secondary structure components with free energy values, generated by the Vienna RNA package/server.
children.text: Vienna local RNA secondary structure format

children.definition: Format of RNA secondary structure in dot-bracket notation, originally generated by the Vienna RNA package/server.
PSL format of alignments, typically generated by BLAT or psLayout. Can be displayed in a genome browser like a sequence annotation track.

A family of similar formats of text annotation, used by BRAT and other tools, known as BioNLP Shared Task format (BioNLP 2009 Shared Task on Event Extraction, BioNLP Shared Task 2011, BioNLP Shared Task 2013), BRAT format, BRAT standoff format, and similar.
Simple multiple sequence (alignment) format for SRS.

GTrack is a generic and optimised tabular format for genome or sequence feature tracks. GTrack unifies the power of other track formats (e.g. GFF3, BED, WIG), and while optimised in size, adds more flexibility, customisation, and automation ("machine understandability").

comment: version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)

It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.
children.definition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.

BTrack is an HDF5-based binary format for genome or sequence feature tracks and their collections, suitable for integrative multi-track analysis. BTrack is a binary, compressed alternative to the GTrack and GSuite formats.

Tree structure of Protein Sequence Database Markup Language generated using Matra software.

GSuite is a tabular format for collections of genome or sequence feature tracks, suitable for integrative multi-track analysis. GSuite contains links to genome/sequence tracks, with additional metadata.

BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.

BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.
XML format for the UniParc database.
Data format for molecular sequence feature information.

comment: HDF is currently supported by many commercial and non-commercial software platforms such as Java, MATLAB/Scilab, Octave, Python and R.
children.definition: HDF is the name of a set of file formats and libraries designed to store and organize large amounts of numerical data, originally developed at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois.

comment: Fully architecture-independent format, regarding both endianness and the ability to mix single/double precision trajectories and I/O libraries. Self-sufficient, it should not require any other files for reading, and all the data should be contained in a single file for easy transport. Temporal compression of data, improving the compression rate of the previous XTC format. Possibility to store meta-data with information about the simulation. Direct access to a particular frame. Efficient parallel I/O.
children.definition: Trajectory Next Generation (TNG) is a format for storage of molecular simulation data. It is designed and implemented by the GROMACS development group, and it is called to be the substitute of the XTC format.

Format used by netCDF software  library for writing and reading chromatography-MS data files.  Also used to store trajectory atom coordinates information, such as the ones obtained by Molecular Dynamics simulations.

comment: The compression is made projecting the Cartesian snapshots collected along the trajectory into an orthogonal space defined by the most relevant eigenvectors obtained by diagonalization of the covariance matrix (PCA). In the compression/decompression process, part of the original information is lost, depending on the final number of eigenvectors chosen. However, with a reasonable choice of the set of eigenvectors the compression typically reduces the trajectory file to less than one tenth of their original size with very acceptable loss of information. Compression with PCAZip can only be applied to unsolvated structures.
children.definition: PCAZip format is a binary compressed file to store atom coordinates based on Essential Dynamics (ED) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA).

The Loom file format is based on HDF5, a standard for storing large numerical datasets. The Loom format is designed to efficiently hold large omics datasets. Typically, such data takes the form of a large matrix of numbers, along with metadata for the rows and columns.

comment: HDF5 is the new version, according to the HDF group, a completely different technology (https://support.hdfgroup.org/products/hdf4/ compared to HDF.

An HDF5 file appears to the user as a directed graph. The nodes of this graph are the higher-level HDF5 objects that are exposed by the HDF5 APIs: Groups, Datasets, Named datatypes. Currently supported by the Python MDTraj package.
children.definition: HDF5 is a data model, library, and file format for storing and managing data, based on Hierarchical Data Format (HDF).

comment: XTC uses the External Data Representation (xdr) routines for writing and reading data which were created for the Unix Network File System (NFS). XTC files use a reduced precision (lossy) algorithm which works multiplying the coordinates by a scaling factor (typically 1000), so converting them to pm (GROMACS standard distance unit is nm). This allows an integer rounding of the values. Several other tricks are performed, such as making use of atom proximity information: atoms close in sequence are usually close in space (e.g. water molecules). That makes XTC format the most efficient in terms of disk usage, in most cases reducing by a factor of 2 the size of any other binary trajectory format.
children.definition: Portable binary format for trajectories produced by GROMACS package.

comment: It is basically a translation of the ASCII atom coordinate format to binary code. The only additional information stored is a magic number that identifies the BinPos format and the number of atoms per snapshot. The remainder is the chain of coordinates binary encoded. A drawback of this format is its architecture dependency. Integers and floats codification depends on the architecture, thus it needs to be converted if working in different platforms (little endian, big endian).
children.definition: Scripps Research Institute BinPos format is a binary formatted file to store atom coordinates.
Binary file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .

comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
children.definition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
Format of trr files that contain the trajectory of a simulation experiment used by GROMACS.
AMBER coordinate/restart file with 6 coordinates per line and decimal format F12.7 (fixed point notation with field width 12 and 7 decimal places)
AMBER trajectory (also called mdcrd), with 10 coordinates per line and format F8.3 (fixed point notation with field width 8 and 3 decimal places).
Textual file format to store trajectory information for a 3D structure .

comment: Formats differ on what they are able to store (coordinates, velocities, topologies) and how they are storing it (raw, compressed, textual, binary).

comment: OME develops open-source software and data format standards for the storage and manipulation of biological microscopy data. It is a joint project between universities, research establishments, industry and the software development community.

An OME-TIFF dataset consists of one or more files in standard TIFF or BigTIFF format, with the file extension .ome.tif or .ome.tiff, and an identical (or in the case of multiple files, nearly identical) string of OME-XML metadata embedded in the ImageDescription tag of each fileâs first IFD (Image File Directory). BigTIFF file extensions are also permitted, with the file extension .ome.tf2, .ome.tf8 or .ome.btf, but note these file extensions are an addition to the original specification, and software using an older version of the specification may not be able to handle these file extensions.

Nexus/paup non-interleaved sequence format.
Format for the Genetic Data Environment (GDE).
Data format for a molecular sequence record.
Data format for a molecular sequence record.
The PED file describes individuals and genetic data and is used by the Plink package.
The MAP file describes SNPs and is used by the Plink package.
The PED/MAP file describes data used by the Plink package.
Data format for a metadata on an individual and their genetic data.
BCF, the binary version of Variant Call Format (VCF) for sequence variation (indels, polymorphisms, structural variation).
Data format used by the SQLite database conformant to the Gemini schema.
Ensembl standard format for variation data.
Variant Call Format (VCF) for sequence variation (indels, polymorphisms, structural variation).
Genome Variation Format (GVF). A GFF3-compatible format with defined header and attribute tags for sequence variation.
Format of sequence variation annotation.

comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
children.definition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).
Format of a report of general information about a specific protein.
PHYLIP file format for continuous quantitative character data.
PHYLIP file format for phylogenetics character frequency data.
Format of phylogenetic continuous quantitative character data.
Format of phylogenetic invariants data.
Format of PHYLIP discrete states data.
Format of phylogenetic discrete states data.
Format of PHYLIP cliques data.
Format of phylogenetic cliques data.
Format of raw (unplotted) phylogenetic data.
CopasiML, the native format of COPASI.
Systems Biology Result Markup Language (SBRML), the standard XML format for simulated or calculated results (e.g. trajectories) of systems biology models.
Data format for a report of information derived from a biological pathway or network.
children.text: Biological pathway or network report format

children.definition: SMILES ARbitrary Target Specification (SMARTS) format for chemical structure specification, which is a subset of the SMILES line notation.
Chemical structure specified in Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System (SMILES) line notation.
Chemical structure specified in IUPAC International Chemical Identifier (InChI) line notation.

comment: An InChIKey identifier is not human- nor machine-readable but is more suitable for web searches than an InChI chemical structure specification.
children.definition: The InChIKey (hashed InChI) is a fixed length (25 character) condensed digital representation of an InChI chemical structure specification. It uniquely identifies a chemical compound.

comment: The general MF query format consists of a series of valid atomic symbols, with an optional number or range.
children.definition: Chemical structure specified by Molecular Formula (MF), including a count of each element in a compound.

BpForms is a string format for concretely representing the primary structures of biopolymers, including DNA, RNA, and proteins that include non-canonical nucleic and amino acids. See https://www.bpforms.org for more information.
Text format of a chemical formula.
Report format on PCR primers and hybridisation oligos as generated by Whitehead primer3 program.
Format of a report on PCR primers or hybridisation oligos in a nucleic acid sequence.
Format of a regular expression pattern from the Prosite database.
A motif in the format generated by the MEME program.
Format of an EMBOSS sequence pattern.
Format of a sequence motif.
Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "small" genomes.
An index of a genome database, indexed for use by the snpeff tool.
Bowtie format for indexed reference genome for "large" genomes.
Index file format used by the samtools package to index TAB-delimited genome position files.
BAM indexing format
Format of a data index of some type.
The Zarr format is an implementation of chunked, compressed, N-dimensional arrays for storing data.
Format of a matrix of 3D-1D scores (amino acid environment probabilities).
Binary format used by MATLAB files to store workspace variables.
Amino acid index format used by the AAindex database.
Data format for an amino acid index.
The Matrix Market matrix (MTX) format stores numerical or pattern matrices in a dense (array format) or sparse (coordinate format) representation.
Format of a matrix (array) of numerical values.
The format of iHOP (Information Hyperlinked over Proteins) text-mining result.
Data format of a report from text mining.

comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
children.definition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.

comment: XYZ files are structured in this way:  First line contains the number of atoms in the file.  Second line contains a title, comment, or filename. Remaining lines contain atom information. Each line starts with the element symbol, followed by x, y and z coordinates in angstroms separated by whitespace. Multiple molecules or frames can be contained within one file, so it supports trajectory storage. XYZ files can be directly represented by a molecular viewer, as they contain all the basic information needed to build the 3D model.
children.definition: The XYZ chemical file format is widely supported by many programs, although many slightly different XYZ file formats coexist (Tinker XYZ, UniChem XYZ, etc.). Basic information stored for each atom in the system are x, y and z coordinates and atom element/atomic number.
Entry format of PDB database in PDB format.
Entry format of PDB database in PDBML (XML) format.

comment: pdb format in EMBOSS.
children.definition: PDB sequence format (ATOM lines).

comment: pdbseq format in EMBOSS.
children.definition: PDB sequence format (SEQRES lines).
Entry format of PDB database in mmCIF format.

comment: pdbnuc format in EMBOSS.
children.definition: PDB nucleotide sequence format (ATOM lines).

comment: pdbnucseq format in EMBOSS.
children.definition: PDB nucleotide sequence format (SEQRES lines).
Format of an entry (or part of an entry) from the PDB database.
Format of trr files that contain the trajectory of a simulation experiment used by GROMACS.

comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.definition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.

comment: version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)

It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.
children.definition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: GROMACS MD package top textual files define an entire structure system topology, either directly, or by including itp files.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: Format of CHARMM Residue Topology Files (RTF), which define groups by including the atoms, the properties of the group, and bond and charge information.
AMBER coordinate/restart file with 6 coordinates per line and decimal format F12.7 (fixed point notation with field width 12 and 7 decimal places)
AMBER trajectory (also called mdcrd), with 10 coordinates per line and format F8.3 (fixed point notation with field width 8 and 3 decimal places).
Data format for a molecular tertiary structure.
GenePix Results (GPR) text file format developed by Axon Instruments that is used to save GenePix Results data.
Data format for raw microarray data.
OpenMS format for quantitation results (LC/MS features).
Mass spectrum file format from QSTAR and QTRAP instruments (ABI/Sciex).
Now deprecated data format of the HUPO Proteomics Standards Initiative.  Replaced by mzML (format_3244).
Output format used by X! series search engines that is based on the XML language BIOML.
XML file format for files containing information about peptide identifications from mass spectrometry data analysis carried out with OpenMS.
mzIdentML is the exchange format for peptides and proteins identified from mass spectra, standardised by HUPO PSI PI. It can be used for outputs of proteomics search engines.

Open data format for the storage, exchange, and processing of peptide sequence assignments of MS/MS scans, intended to provide a common data output format for many different MS/MS search engines and subsequent peptide-level analyses.

comment: Each file contains one header line for the known or assumed charge and the mass of the precursor peptide ion, calculated from the measured *m*/*z* and the charge. This one line was then followed by all the *m*/*z*, intensity pairs that represent the spectrum.
children.definition: Spectral data format file where each spectrum is written to a separate file.

comment: No human-consumable information about this format is available (see http://tools.proteomecenter.org/wiki/index.php?title=Formats:protXML).
children.definition: A format for storage, exchange, and processing of protein identifications created from ms/ms-derived peptide sequence data.

comment: JCAMP-DX is an ASCII based format and therefore not very compact even though it includes standards for file compression.
children.definition: A standardized file format for data exchange in mass spectrometry, initially developed for infrared spectrometry.
Common file format for proteomics mass spectrometric data developed at the Seattle Proteome Center/Institute for Systems Biology.

comment: Proprietary format for which documentation is not available.
children.definition: Proprietary file format for mass spectrometry data from Thermo Scientific.

comment: Proprietary format for which documentation is not available, but used by multiple tools.
children.definition: Proprietary file format for mass spectrometry data from Waters.

comment: Files includes *m*/*z*, intensity pairs separated by headers; headers can contain a bit more information, including search engine instructions.
children.definition: Mascot Generic Format.  Encodes multiple MS/MS spectra in a single file.
mzTab is a tab-delimited format for mass spectrometry-based proteomics and metabolomics results.
"Raw" result file from Mascot database search.

comment: imzML data is recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra.
children.definition: ibd is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging data.
TraML (Transition Markup Language) is the format for mass spectrometry transitions, standardised by HUPO PSI MSS.
Format supported by the Tide tool for identifying peptides from tandem mass spectra.

comment: This format corresponds to an SQLite database, and you can look into the files with e.g. SQLiteStudio3. There are also some readers (http://doi.org/10.1021/pr2005154) and converters (http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jprot.2015.06.015) for this format available, which re-engineered the database schema, but there is no official DB schema specification of Thermo Scientific for the format.
children.definition: Proprietary mass-spectrometry format of Thermo Scientific's ProteomeDiscoverer software.

Format used by netCDF software  library for writing and reading chromatography-MS data files.  Also used to store trajectory atom coordinates information, such as the ones obtained by Molecular Dynamics simulations.

mzQuantML is the format for quantitation values associated with peptides, proteins and small molecules from mass spectra, standardised by HUPO PSI PI. It can be used for outputs of quantitation software for proteomics.

comment: The focus of qcML is towards mass spectrometry based proteomics, but the format is suitable for metabolomics and sequencing as well.
children.definition: qcML is an XML format for quality-related data of mass spectrometry and other high-throughput measurements.

comment: Differ from .dta only in subtleties of the header line format and content and support the added feature of being able to.
children.definition: Spectral data file similar to dta.
PRIDE XML is an XML format for mass spectra, peptide and protein identifications, and metadata about a corresponding measurement, sample, experiment.
Format of peak list files from Andromeda search engine (MaxQuant) that consist of arbitrarily many spectra.
"Raw" result file from SEQUEST database search.

comment: imzML data are recorded in 2 files: '.imzXML' is a metadata XML file based on mzML by HUPO-PSI, and '.ibd' is a binary file containing the mass spectra. This entry is for the metadata XML file
children.definition: imzML metadata is a data format for mass spectrometry imaging metadata.
OpenMS format for grouping features in one map or across several maps.

comment: mzML is the successor and unifier of the mzData format developed by PSI and mzXML developed at the Seattle Proteome Center.
children.definition: mzML format for raw spectrometer output data, standardised by HUPO PSI MSS.
Format for mass pectra and derived data, include peptide sequences etc.

Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but without ambiguity or non-sequence characters.
Alphabet for molecular sequence with possible unknown positions but without non-sequence characters.

BioXSD-schema-based XML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, Web services, and object-oriented programming.

BpForms is a string format for concretely representing the primary structures of biopolymers, including DNA, RNA, and proteins that include non-canonical nucleic and amino acids. See https://www.bpforms.org for more information.

Mash sketch is a format for sequence / sequence checksum information. To make a sketch, each k-mer in a sequence is hashed, which creates a pseudo-random identifier. By sorting these hashes, a small subset from the top of the sorted list can represent the entire sequence.
Alphabet for the consensus of two or more molecular sequences.
Alphabet for a molecular sequence with possible unknown positions and possible ambiguity characters.
Raw sequence format with no non-sequence characters.

BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.

BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.
Format of a raw molecular sequence (i.e. the alphabet used).
Format for reports on a protein family.
Format of bibliographic reference as used by the PubMed database.
XML format for collected entries from biobliographic databases MEDLINE and PubMed.
CiteXplore 'core' citation format including title, journal, authors and abstract.
CiteXplore 'all' citation format includes all known details such as Mesh terms and cross-references.

comment: Bibliographic reference information including citation information is included
children.definition: Format for abstracts of scientific articles from the Medline database.
Format of a bibliographic reference.
The format of an entry from the HET group dictionary (HET groups from PDB files).

comment: BcForms is related to http://edamontology.org/format_3909. (BcForms uses BpForms to describe subunits which are DNA, RNA, or protein polymers.) However, that format isn't the parent of BcForms. BcForms is similarly related to SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301).
children.definition: BcForms is a format for abstractly describing the molecular structure (atoms and bonds) of macromolecular complexes as a collection of subunits and crosslinks. Each subunit can be described with BpForms (http://edamontology.org/format_3909) or SMILES (http://edamontology.org/data_2301). BcForms uses an ontology of crosslinks to abstract the chemical details of crosslinks from the descriptions of complexes (see https://bpforms.org/crosslink.html).
An MDL Molfile is a file format for holding information about the atoms, bonds, connectivity and coordinates of a molecule.
Complete, portable representation of a SYBYL molecule. ASCII file which contains all the information needed to reconstruct a SYBYL molecule.
SDF is one of a family of chemical-data file formats developed by MDL Information Systems; it is intended especially for structural information.
Format of a report on a chemical compound.
Format of a report from the HMMER package on the emission and transition counts of a hidden Markov model.
Data format for the emission and transition counts of a hidden Markov model.
children.text: HMM emission and transition counts format

children.definition: Format for distances, such as Branch Score distance, between two or more phylogenetic trees as used by the Phylip package.
Format for phylogenetic tree distance data.
Format used by the HMMER package for of an alignment of a hidden Markov model against a sequence database.
Format used by the HMMER package for an alignment of a sequence against a hidden Markov model database.
Format for alignment of molecular sequences to MEME profiles (position-dependent scoring matrices) as generated by the MAST tool from the MEME package.
Data format for a sequence-profile alignment.

Tab-delimited text file format used by Eland - the read-mapping program distributed by Illumina with its sequencing analysis pipeline - which maps short Solexa sequence reads to the human reference genome.
AFG is a single text-based file assembly format  that holds read and consensus information together
Sequence assembly project file EXP format.

comment: It is called FASTG, like FASTA, but the G stands for âgraphâ.
children.definition: FASTG is a format for faithfully representing genome assemblies in the face of allelic polymorphism and assembly uncertainty.
Common Assembly Format (CAF). A sequence assembly format including contigs, base-call qualities, and other metadata.
Text format for sequence assembly data.
AGP is a tabular format for a sequence assembly (a contig, a scaffold/supercontig, or a chromosome).
ACE sequence assembly format including contigs, base-call qualities, and other metadata (version Aug 1998 and onwards).
Format for sequence assembly data.
BioJSON is a JSON format of single multiple sequence alignments, with their annotations, features, and custom visualisation and application settings for the Jalview workbench.
An alignment format generated by PRANK/PRANKSTER consisting of four elements: newick, nodes, selection and model.

BioXSD-schema-based XML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, Web services, and object-oriented programming.
XML format for molecular sequence alignment information.
A set of XML compliant markup components for describing multiple sequence alignments.
Alignment format for start and end of matches between sequence pairs.
Alignment format for score values for pairs of sequences.
Format of multiple sequences aligned by DIALIGN package.

comment: FASTA format extended for color space information.
children.definition: Color space FASTA format sequence variant.

The A2M format is used as the primary format for multiple alignments of protein or nucleic-acid sequences in the SAM suite of tools. It is a small modification of FASTA format for sequences and is compatible with most tools that read FASTA.

comment: Typically generated by Multiz and TBA aligners; can be displayed in a genome browser like a sequence annotation track. This should not be confused with MIRA Assembly Format or Mutation Annotation Format.
children.definition: Multiple Alignment Format (MAF) supporting alignments of whole genomes with rearrangements, directions, multiple pieces to the alignment, and so forth.

comment: The format is clustal-like and includes annotation of domain family classification information.
children.definition: EMBASSY 'domain alignment file' (DAF) format, containing a sequence alignment of protein domains belonging to the same SCOP or CATH family.
EMBOSS alignment format for debugging trace of full internal data content.
A multiple alignment in vertical format, as used in the AMPS (Alignment of Multiple Protein Sequences) pacakge.
Fasta format for (aligned) sequences.
FASTA format including NCBI-style IDs.
Simple multiple sequence (alignment) format for SRS.
Pearson MARKX2 alignment format.
Pearson MARKX0 alignment format.
Pearson MARKX3 alignment format.
Pearson MARKX10 alignment format.
Pearson MARKX1 alignment format.
Some variant of Pearson MARKX alignment format.
EMBOSS simple sequence pair alignment format.
ClustalW format for (aligned) sequences.
FASTA-style format for multiple sequences aligned by HMMER package to an HMM.
T-Coffee program alignment format.
Stockholm multiple sequence alignment format (used by Pfam and Rfam).

comment: GCG SSF (single sequence file) file format.
children.definition: GCG sequence file format.
GCG MSF (multiple sequence file) file format.

comment: RSF-format files contain one or more sequences that may or may not be related. In addition to the sequence data, each sequence can be annotated with descriptive sequence information (from the GCG manual).
children.definition: Rich sequence format.
Some format based on the GCG format.
Nexus/paup interleaved sequence format.
Treecon format for (aligned) sequences.
EMBOSS simple multiple alignment format.

The A2M format is used as the primary format for multiple alignments of protein or nucleic-acid sequences in the SAM suite of tools. It is a small modification of FASTA format for sequences and is compatible with most tools that read FASTA.
SELEX format for (aligned) sequences.
Mega non-interleaved format for (typically aligned) sequences.
Mega format for (typically aligned) sequences.
Some variant of Mega format for (typically aligned) sequences.
Phylip non-interleaved format for (aligned) sequences.

comment: It differs from Phylip sequential format (format_1997) on length of the ID sequence. There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. Sequences IDs must be padded to the longest ID length.
children.definition: Phylip multiple alignment sequence format, less stringent than PHYLIP sequential format (format_1998).
Phylip format for (aligned) sequences.

comment: It differs from Phylip Format (format_1997) on length of the ID sequence. There no length restrictions on the ID, but whitespaces aren't allowed in the sequence ID/Name because one space separates the longest ID and the beginning of the sequence. Sequences IDs must be padded to the longest ID length.
children.definition: Phylip multiple alignment sequence format, less stringent than PHYLIP format.
Some variant of Phylip format for (aligned) sequences.
Nexus/paup non-interleaved sequence format.
EMBOSS simple sequence pair alignment format.
Text format for molecular sequence alignment information.
RNA Markup Language.
. proBAM is an adaptation of BAM (format_2572), which was extended to meet specific requirements entailed by proteomics data.
axt format of alignments, typically produced from BLASTZ.
LAV format of alignments generated by BLASTZ and LASTZ.
PSL format of alignments, typically generated by BLAT or psLayout. Can be displayed in a genome browser like a sequence annotation track.

comment: The format supports short and long reads (up to 128Mbp) produced by different sequencing platforms and is used to hold mapped data within the GATK and across the Broad Institute, the Sanger Centre, and throughout the 1000 Genomes project.
children.definition: Sequence Alignment/Map (SAM) format for alignment of nucleotide sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). May contain base-call and alignment qualities and other data.

BAM format, the binary, BGZF-formatted compressed version of SAM format for alignment of nucleotide sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). May contain base-call and alignment qualities and other data.
EBI Application Result XML is a format returned by sequence similarity search Web services at EBI.
Pileup format of alignment of sequences (e.g. sequencing reads) to (a) reference sequence(s). Contains aligned bases per base of the reference sequence(s).
Simple sequence pair (alignment) format for SRS.
Reference-based compression of alignment format
Data format for molecular sequence alignment information that can hold sequence alignment(s) of only 2 sequences.

BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.

BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.
Binary format used by the ARB software suite
Data format for molecular sequence alignment information.
Format of affymetrix gene cluster files (hc-genes.txt, hc-chips.txt) from hierarchical clustering.
Format used for clusters of nucleotide sequences.
Format used for clusters of protein sequences.
Format used for clusters of molecular sequences.
Format of Affymetrix data file of information about (raw) expression levels of the individual probes.

Proprietary file format for (raw) BeadArray data used by genomewide profiling platforms from Illumina Inc. This format is output directly from the scanner and stores summary intensities for each probe-type on an array.

comment: ISA-TAB is based on MAGE-TAB. Other than tabular, the ISA model can also be represented in RDF, and in JSON (compliable with a set of defined JSON Schemata).
children.definition:
The Investigation / Study / Assay (ISA) tab-delimited (TAB) format incorporates metadata from 
experiments employing a combination of technologies.
Format of Affymetrix data file of information about (normalised) expression levels of the individual probes.
MAGE-ML XML format for microarray expression data, standardised by MGED (now FGED).
Reporter Code Count-A data file (.csv) output by the Nanostring nCounter Digital Analyzer, which contains gene sample information, probe information and probe counts.
Format of Affymetrix data file of raw image data.
The Zarr format is an implementation of chunked, compressed, N-dimensional arrays for storing data.
MAGE-TAB textual format for microarray expression data, standardised by MGED (now FGED).

The Loom file format is based on HDF5, a standard for storing large numerical datasets. The Loom format is designed to efficiently hold large omics datasets. Typically, such data takes the form of a large matrix of numbers, along with metadata for the rows and columns.
Format of the cytoscape input file of gene expression ratios or values are specified over one or more experiments.
Tab-delimited text files of GenePattern that contain a column for each sample, a row for each gene, and an expression value for each gene in each sample.
The Matrix Market matrix (MTX) format stores numerical or pattern matrices in a dense (array format) or sparse (coordinate format) representation.
Format of a file of gene expression data, e.g. a gene expression matrix or profile.
phyloXML is a standardised XML format for phylogenetic trees, networks, and associated data.
NeXML is a standardised XML format for rich phyloinformatic data.
XML format for a phylogenetic tree.
Dendrogram (tree file) format generated by ClustalW.
Phylogenetic tree data format used by the PHYLIP program.
Raw data file format used by Phylip from which a phylogenetic tree is directly generated or plotted.
Phylogenetic tree Newick (text) format.
Phylogenetic tree TreeCon (text) format.
The format of an entry from the TreeBASE database of phylogenetic data.
The format of an entry from the TreeFam database of phylogenetic data.
Phylogenetic tree Nexus (text) format.
Text format for a phylogenetic tree.
Data format for a phylogenetic tree.
NLP format used by a specific type of corpus (collection of texts).
An NLP format used for annotated textual documents.
Data format used in Natural Language Processing.

A report format for the kinetics of enzyme-catalysed reaction(s) in a format generated by EMBOSS findkm. This includes Michaelis Menten plot, Hanes Woolf plot, Michaelis Menten constant (Km) and maximum velocity (Vmax).
Data format for reports on enzyme kinetics.

comment: The high similarity in the functional form of the two potential energy functions used by AMBER and CHARMM force-fields gives rise to the possible use of one force-field within the other MD engine. Therefore, the conversion of PSF files to AMBER Prmtop format is possible with the use of AMBER chamber (CHARMM - AMBER) program.
children.definition: X-Plor Protein Structure Files (PSF) are structure topology files used by NAMD and CHARMM molecular simulations programs. PSF files contain six main sections of interest: atoms, bonds, angles, dihedrals, improper dihedrals (force terms used to maintain planarity) and cross-terms.

comment: GROMACS itp files are used also to define position restrictions on the molecule, or to define the force field parameters for a particular ligand.
children.definition: GROMACS itp files (include topology) contain structure topology information, and are tipically included in GROMACS topology files (GROMACS top). Itp files are used to define individual (or multiple) components of a topology as a separate file. This is particularly useful if there is a molecule that is used frequently, and also reduces the size of the system topology file, splitting it in different parts.

comment: version 7 is written to distinguish it from old versions of AMBER Prmtop. Similarly to HDF5, it is a completely different format, according to AMBER group: a drastic change to the file format occurred with the 2004 release of Amber 7 (http://ambermd.org/prmtop.pdf)

It can be modified manually, but as the size of the system increases, the hand-editing becomes increasingly complex. AMBER Parameter-Topology file format is used extensively by the AMBER software suite and is referred to as the Prmtop file for short.
children.definition: AMBER Prmtop file (version 7) is a structure topology text file divided in several sections designed to be parsed easily using simple Fortran code. Each section contains particular topology information, such as atom name, charge, mass, angles, dihedrals, etc.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: GROMACS MD package top textual files define an entire structure system topology, either directly, or by including itp files.

comment: There is currently no tool available for conversion between GROMACS topology format and other formats, due to the internal differences in both approaches. There is, however, a method to convert small molecules parameterized with AMBER force-field into GROMACS format, allowing simulations of these systems with GROMACS MD package.
children.definition: Format of CHARMM Residue Topology Files (RTF), which define groups by including the atoms, the properties of the group, and bond and charge information.

comment: Many different file formats exist describing structural molecular topology. Tipically, each MD package or simulation software works with their own implementation (e.g. GROMACS top, CHARMM psf, AMBER prmtop).
children.definition: Format of topology files; containing the static information of a structure molecular system that is needed for a molecular simulation.

comment: For SOLiD data, the sequence is in color space, except the first position. The quality values are those of the Sanger format.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for SOLiD data.
FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from 454 sequencers.

comment: Starting in Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8, the Phred scores 0 to 2 have a slightly different meaning. The values 0 and 1 are no longer used and the value 2, encoded by ASCII 66 "B", is used also at the end of reads as a Read Segment Quality Control Indicator.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) from Illumina 1.5 and before Illumina 1.8.

comment: Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format can encode a Solexa/Illumina quality score from -5 to 62 using ASCII 59 to 126 (although in raw read data Solexa scores from -5 to 40 only are expected)
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences) for Solexa/Illumina 1.0 format.

comment: Phred quality scores  are defined as a property which is logarithmically related to the base-calling error probabilities.
children.definition: FASTQ format subset for Phred sequencing quality score data only (no sequences).

comment: uses the TeX typesetting program format
children.definition: format for the LaTeX document preparation system

comment: The DSSP database is built using the DSSP application which defines secondary structure, geometrical features and solvent exposure of proteins, given atomic coordinates in PDB format.
children.definition: Format of an entry from the DSSP database (Dictionary of Secondary Structure in Proteins).
Entry format of the HSSP database (Homology-derived Secondary Structure in Proteins).

comment: The report (for example http://www.cathdb.info/domain/1cukA01) includes CATH codes for levels in the hierarchy for the domain, level descriptions and relevant data and links.
children.definition: Format of summary of domain classification information for a CATH domain.

comment: This concept exists only to assist EDAM maintenance and navigation in graphical browsers.  It does not add semantic information. The concept branch under 'Format (typed)' provides an alternative organisation of the concepts nested under the other top-level branches ('Binary', 'HTML', 'RDF', 'Text' and 'XML'. All concepts under here are already included under those branches.
children.definition: A placeholder concept for visual navigation by dividing data formats by the content of the data that is represented.

BioJSON is a JSON format of single multiple sequence alignments, with their annotations, features, and custom visualisation and application settings for the Jalview workbench.
A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.

children.definition: BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.
JSON format of annotated scientific text used by PubAnnotations and other tools.
JavaScript Object Notation format; a lightweight, text-based format to represent tree-structured data using key-value pairs.

BioYAML is a BioXSD-schema-based YAML format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web APIs, human readability and editting, and object-oriented programming.

comment: Data in YAML format can be serialised into text, or binary format.
YAML version 1.2 is a superset of JSON; prior versions were "not strictly compatible".
children.definition: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language) is a human-readable tree-structured data serialisation language.
A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.

A format of text annotation using the linked-data Open Annotation Data Model, serialised typically in RDF or JSON-LD.

children.definition: BioJSON is a BioXSD-schema-based JSON format of sequence-based data and some other common data - sequence records, alignments, feature records, references to resources, and more - optimised for integrative bioinformatics, web applications and APIs, and object-oriented programming.

DAS sequence (XML) format (any type).

Open data format for the storage, exchange, and processing of peptide sequence assignments of MS/MS scans, intended to provide a common data output format for many different MS/MS search engines and subsequent peptide-level analyses.

MAGE-ML XML format for microarray expression data, standardised by MGED (now FGED).

Biological Connection Markup Language (BCML) is an XML format for biological pathways.

comment: OSCAR (Open-Source Chemistry Analysis Routines) software performs chemistry-specific parsing of chemical documents. It attempts to identify chemical names, ontology concepts, and chemical data from a document.

XML format as produced by the NCBI Blast package v2.
XML format for XML Schema.
Chado-XML format is a direct mapping of the Chado relational schema into XML.
